S3.T1.caption:
Table 1: Feature learning by FedAvg. We report the test accuracy of a ResNet-18 after (centralized) retraining of the last â„“â„“\ell layers on CIFAR10. The earlier (7âˆ’â„“)7â„“(7-\ell) layers are frozen to either random initialization or to the weights of a FedAvg-trained model. The difference measures utility of the (7âˆ’â„“)7â„“(7-\ell) layers learnt by FedAvg. The baseline FedAvg model without additional training gets 56.956.956.9% accuracy.
We see that all layers of the FedAvg model contain useful information.
S3.T1.table:
Layers retrained Accuracy (%) Accuracy (%) Improvement (%)
Random init FedAvg init (FedAvg - Random)
1/7 last layer 35.37 77.93
2/7 last layers 67.33 87.04
3/7 last layers 80.18 89.28
4/7 last layers 88.03 90.57
5/7 last layers 91.34 91.61
6/7 last layers 91.78 91.91
references: Given a FedAvg-trained model, we can use centralized training to retrain only the last â„“â„“\ell layers while keeping the rest of the (7âˆ’â„“)7â„“(7-\ell) layers (or ResNet blocks) frozen. We can also perform this procedure starting from a randomly initialized model. The performance difference between these two models can be attributed to the information content of the frozen (7âˆ’â„“)7â„“(7-\ell) layers of the FedAvg model. TableÂ 1 summarizes the results of this experiment. The large difference in accuracy (up to 42.642.642.6%) indicates the initial layers of the FedAvg model have learned useful features. There continues to be a gap between the FedAvg features and random features in the earlier layers as well,111The significant decrease in the gap as we go down the layers may be because of the skip connections in the lower ResNet blocks which allow the random frozen layers to be sidestepped. This underestimates the true utility and information content in the earlier FedAvg layers. meaning that all layers of the FedAvg model learn useful features. We conjecture this is because from the perspective of earlier layers which perform simple edge detection, the tasks are independent of labels and the clients are i.i.d. However, the higher layers are more specialized and the effect of the heterogeneity is stronger.

references: TableÂ 2 displays the top-1 accuracy of all algorithm on the three tasks with varying degrees of data heterogeneity. We evaluated each algorithms on each task under four degrees of data heterogeneity. Smaller #C and Î±ğ›¼\alpha in TableÂ 2 correspond to higher heterogeneity.

In comparison with FedAdam and FedDyn. We compare TCT to FedAdamÂ [Reddi etÂ al., 2021] and FedDynÂ [Acar etÂ al., 2021] in TableÂ 3. We consider four settings in TableÂ 3, including CIFAR10 (#C=2#C2\texttt{\#C}=2), CIFAR10 (Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1), CIFAR100 (Î±=0.001ğ›¼0.001\alpha=0.001), and CIFAR100 (Î±=0.01ğ›¼0.01\alpha=0.01).
For FedDyn, we perform similar hyperparameter selection as FedAvg; i.e., select local learning rate from {0.1,0.01,0.001}0.10.010.001\{0.1,0.01,0.001\}. For FedAdam, following recommendation byÂ [Reddi etÂ al., 2021], we set the global learning rate as Î·global=0.1subscriptğœ‚global0.1\eta_{\mathrm{global}}=0.1 and select local learning rate from {10âˆ’1,10âˆ’1.5,10âˆ’2,10âˆ’2.5,10âˆ’3}superscript101superscript101.5superscript102superscript102.5superscript103\{10^{-1},10^{-1.5},10^{-2},10^{-2.5},10^{-3}\}.
Similar to results in TableÂ 2, we find that TCT significantly outperforms the existing methods in high data heterogeneity settings.

In TableÂ 5 and FigureÂ 7, we provide additional results of the effect of pre-training for FedAvg and TCT on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 datasets. For both methods, we use the ResNet-18 pre-trained on ImageNet-1kÂ [He etÂ al., 2016] as the initialization.
We use FedAvg (last layer) to denote applying FedAvg on learning the last linear layer of the model, i.e., layers except for the last linear layer are freezed during training.
Compared to results in TableÂ 2, we find that using pre-trained model as initialization largely improves the performance of both FedAvg and TCT. However, FedAvg still suffers from data heterogeneity. In contrast, TCT achieves similar performance as the centralized setting on both datasets across different degrees of data heterogeneity.

In SectionÂ 5, we use batch normalizationÂ [Ioffe and Szegedy, 2015] as the default normalization layer on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 datasets, and we denote the ResNet-18 with batch normalization layers by ResNet-18-BN. In TableÂ 4, we consider group normalizationÂ [Wu and He, 2018] on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 and let ResNet-18-GN denote the ResNet-18 with group normalization.
We set num_groups=2 in group normalization layers. As shown in TableÂ 4, TCT achieves better performance than FedAvg with ResNet-18-GN on both CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 datasets. Our experiments indicate that in extremely heterogeneous settings, group norm is insufficient to fix FedAvg.

references: From our experiments, we find that small local learning rates (Î·â‰¤10âˆ’4ğœ‚superscript104\eta\leq 10^{-4}) achieve good train/test accuracy performance for TCT with the normalization step. When the normalization step in TCT is applied, larger local learning rates diverge. Meanwhile, local learning rates from [10âˆ’6,10âˆ’4]superscript106superscript104[10^{-6},10^{-4}] achieve similar performance for TCT (as shown in TableÂ 7). On the other hand, without the normalization step, TCT with large learning rate (Î·âˆˆ[0.01,0.5]ğœ‚0.010.5\eta\in[0.01,0.5]) does not diverge. When running more communication rounds, TCT (without the normalization step) with large learning rate achieves similar performance as the default TCT (with the normalization step).

As mentioned in Reddi etÂ al. [2021], FedAdam is more robust to the choice of local learning rate compared to FedAvg. We conduct additional ablations on the effect of local learning rate for TCT as well as FedAdamÂ [Reddi etÂ al., 2021] on the CIFAR10 dataset.
For each algorithm, we first select a base local learning rate Î·basesubscriptğœ‚base\eta_{\mathrm{base}} and then vary the local learning rate Î·âˆˆ{Î·baseâ‹…100,Î·baseâ‹…10âˆ’0.5,Î·baseâ‹…10âˆ’1.0,Î·baseâ‹…10âˆ’1.5}ğœ‚â‹…subscriptğœ‚basesuperscript100â‹…subscriptğœ‚basesuperscript100.5â‹…subscriptğœ‚basesuperscript101.0â‹…subscriptğœ‚basesuperscript101.5\eta\in\{\eta_{\mathrm{base}}\cdot 10^{0},\eta_{\mathrm{base}}\cdot 10^{-0.5},\eta_{\mathrm{base}}\cdot 10^{-1.0},\eta_{\mathrm{base}}\cdot 10^{-1.5}\}. The results are summarized in TableÂ 7. Compared to FedAdam, we find that TCT is much less sensitive to the choice of local learning rate.
